title: About
text:
This blog will contain somewhat technical thoughts around software, systems, and control.
Of particular interest is dynamic programming. We will try to get the gist of it, and especially to figure out how we can see similarities between how it is used in control and how it is used in computer science.

title: A Quarto Book
text:
Here is how I created a book using Quarto.
I started with installing Quarto, using the downloadable file found on the Quarto Get Started page.
Starting out with R Studio as the IDE, thinking that this was the only option, I switched to using VSCode.
Using the VSCode Quarto extension, I could now create a book, using Command-Shift-P (I am on a Mac) and the choosing the function Quarto: Create Project.
This led to a book with two chapters, a reference section with a reference to Donald E Knuthâ€™s Literate Programming.
I could render the book, in html and pdf, using the command (in the VSCode Terminal)
quarto render
The pdf rendering relied on LaTeX, which I installed from this MacTex page.
You can read about LaTex recommendations for Quarto in the Quarto docs.
The book can be viewed, in a browser, by issuing the command
quarto preview
The pdf version of the book can be found in the directory _book (which was created as a result of the quarto render command)


Looking in the file _quarto.yml, I found placeholders for title and author, as
  title: "intocontrol_book"
  author: "Norah Jones"
I changed those, and also the date, which was on the line below where the author was stated.



I wrote some equations, in the intro.qmd file, using LaTex as I learned it when I was working in University.
Using the notation
$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot x &= Ax + Bu \\
y &= Cx + Du
\end{aligned}
$$
I got a nicely displayed equation, however without any equation number.
Changing the notation, with inspiration from Stack Overflow and the Quarto documentation, to
$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot x &= Ax + Bu \\
y &= Cx + Du
\end{aligned}
$${#eq-state-space}
I saw that an equation number appeared.

text:

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in my Quarto blog. Welcome!

I am experimenting with Quarto, and publishing on github.io.
More news to come later.
